table-wrap.anchoringText: In December 2015, 9 active production wells, 4 non-productive wells (NP), 2 temporary abandoned (ATA) wells, 2 permanently abandoned (APA) wells and 19 dry permanently abandoned (DPA) wells were reported, i.e. a total of 36 wells in Block XYZ. Table N°1 shows the conditions and the adjusted parameters of the hyperbolic declined curve of the analyzed wells (9 active + 3 NP):
table-wrap.label: Table N°1
table-wrap.caption: Conditions and adjusted parameters of the analyzed oil wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Conditions and adjusted parameters of the analyzed oil wells

table-wrap.anchoringText: Using the production history and the Arps’ decline curves analysis, three deterministic production scenarios are built, and, consequently, three performance levels - Low, Base and High - are obtained. To build these scenarios, in each adjustment the measurements weight factors were changed according to the expert’s criterion. Therefore, three adjustment curves are obtained: one exponential (b=0 - Low) and two hyperbolic with a non-zero “b” parameter (see Table Nº2). A correlation between b and D parameters is applied.
table-wrap.label: Table N°2
table-wrap.caption: Estimated parameters for deterministic scenarios in Block XYZ.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimated parameters for deterministic scenarios in Block XYZ.

table-wrap.anchoringText: Using the decline curves of the three scenarios, the proved developed reserves (PD) up to December 31, 2034 can be estimated. The results are shown in Table Nº 3.
table-wrap.label: Table N°3
table-wrap.caption: Proved Developed Reserves (PD) up to December 31, 2034 for the three deterministic scenarios in Block XYZ

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proved Developed Reserves (PD) up to December 31, 2034 for the three deterministic scenarios in Block XYZ

table-wrap.anchoringText: The Proved Non-Developed reserves are estimated according to the drilling chronogram proposed for the Block XYZ, which is based on a well drilled per year beginning on January 1st, 2018. The initial flow rates are predicted from well analogy (actual wells Nº3, 4, 5 and 10) and applying Darcy’s equation with an estimated drainage radius. Neutron log profiles are available for wells Nº 3, 4, 5, and 10 (Table Nº 1) and they allow to estimate the average drainage radii of the Pariñas Inferior and Mogollón productive zones and extrapolate them to the new 4 infill wells. Table N°4 shows the estimated flow rates for the 4 infill wells which will be included in Block XYZ
table-wrap.label: Table N°4
table-wrap.caption: Drilling chronogram of infill wells

table-wrap.anchoringText: Based on the estimated “b” and “D” parameters of declined curves for the latest drilled wells (Table Nº 5), a type well is generated with average values for “b” and “D”, taking into account that “D” increases with field depletion.
table-wrap.label: Table N° 5
table-wrap.caption: Characteristics of the latest perforated wells in Block XYZ

formatted-caption.caption-text: Characteristics of the latest perforated wells in Block XYZ

table-wrap.anchoringText: Tables N° 6 and N° 7 display the formations properties (Pariñas inferior and Mogollón) that contribute to the 1PX Project. We use two extreme values (P90 and P10) and a most likely value (mode) for each input variable to the volumetric equation that estimates PND reserves. This information comes from geological models (area and thickness), well logging (porosity and initial water saturation), laboratory measurements (porosity, oil formation volume factor) and well analogies joint with the expert’s opinion (recovery factor).
table-wrap.label: Table N° 6
table-wrap.caption: Properties of the Pariñas Inferior Formation. Project IPX.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Properties of the Pariñas Inferior Formation. Project IPX.

table-wrap.anchoringText: Tables N° 6 and N° 7 display the formations properties (Pariñas inferior and Mogollón) that contribute to the 1PX Project. We use two extreme values (P90 and P10) and a most likely value (mode) for each input variable to the volumetric equation that estimates PND reserves. This information comes from geological models (area and thickness), well logging (porosity and initial water saturation), laboratory measurements (porosity, oil formation volume factor) and well analogies joint with the expert’s opinion (recovery factor).
table-wrap.label: Table N°7
table-wrap.caption: Properties of the Mogollón Formation. Project 1PX.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Properties of the Mogollón Formation. Project 1PX.

table-wrap.anchoringText: In a similar way, the EUR results for 3EX, 4EX and 5EX projects are estimated. They are shown in Table N° 8.
table-wrap.label: Table N° 8
table-wrap.caption: Proved Undeveloped Reserves of Lot XYZ (4 Drillings).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proved Undeveloped Reserves of Lot XYZ (4 Drillings).

table-wrap.anchoringText: The hybrid model begins with the estimation of the type well decline curve with average “b” and “D” parameters values, computed using the “b” and “D” values estimated for the latest 4 drilled wells. Based on the expert’s experience, three cases are generated - Low, Base and High - as shown in Table N° 9.
table-wrap.label: Table N° 9
table-wrap.caption: Average “b” y “D” Type Curve parameters for Low, Base and High Cases.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Average “b” y “D” Type Curve parameters for Low, Base and High Cases.

table-wrap.anchoringText: For each project, Table Nº10 shows the 50% percentile monthly production forecast from the beginning of the production to the economic limit of 5 Bbl/d. In Table N° 11 the estimated dates of wells abandonment can be seen. They are all previous to December 31, 2034, end of the lease contract.
table-wrap.label: Table N° 10
table-wrap.caption: 50 % percentile monthly production forecast for PND Reserves Projects

formatted-caption.caption-text: 50 % percentile monthly production forecast for PND Reserves Projects

table-wrap.anchoringText: For each project, Table Nº10 shows the 50% percentile monthly production forecast from the beginning of the production to the economic limit of 5 Bbl/d. In Table N° 11 the estimated dates of wells abandonment can be seen. They are all previous to December 31, 2034, end of the lease contract.
table-wrap.label: Table N°11
table-wrap.caption: Project Schedule until abandonment.

table-wrap.anchoringText: According to the Hybrid Model, the CDF of the reserves (1P, 2P and 3P) estimated by the probabilistic volumetric method and the CDF of the PND reserves obtained by the probabilistic decline curve method must be integrated. In this way, both probabilistic distributions are correlated and normalized in order to find a unique CDF of reserves. Fig. N° 9 and Table N° 12 illustrate how the reserves estimated by probabilistic decline curve method are coupled coherently with those obtained by the probabilistic volumetric method.
table-wrap.label: Table N°12
table-wrap.caption: Reserves estimated by the Hybrid Method for each project

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reserves estimated by the Hybrid Method for each project

tr.th: EUR 1PX- Método Volumétrico Probabilistico (Reservas IP, 2P y 3P)
EUR IPX - Método de Curva Declinación Probabilistica (PND)
EUR 3EX - Mètodo Volumètrico Probabilistico (Reservas IP, 2P y 3P)
EUR 3EX - Método de Curva Declinación Probabilistica (PND)
EUR4EX - Mètodo Volumètrico Probabilistico (Reservas IP, 2P y 3P)
EUR4EX - Mètodo de Curva Declinación Probabilistica (PND)
EUR5EX- Método Volumètrico Probabilistico (Reservas IP, 2P y 3P)
EUR5EX- Método de Curva Declinación Probabilistica (PND)

table-wrap.anchoringText: Finally, for each Project, we compute the certainty minimum condition of the proved reserves with the Hybrid Method (see Table N° 13). In Table N° 14 the certainty levels (from 100 % to 0 %) within the 1P reserves for all the projects (1PX, 3EX, 4EX, 5EX) are visualized.
table-wrap.label: Table N°13
table-wrap.caption: Minimum Certainty condition of the proved reserves estimated with the Hybrid Method.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Minimum Certainty condition of the proved reserves estimated with the Hybrid Method.

table-wrap.anchoringText: Finally, for each Project, we compute the certainty minimum condition of the proved reserves with the Hybrid Method (see Table N° 13). In Table N° 14 the certainty levels (from 100 % to 0 %) within the 1P reserves for all the projects (1PX, 3EX, 4EX, 5EX) are visualized.
table-wrap.label: Table N°14
table-wrap.caption: Certainty levels (from 100% to 0%) within the 1P reserves.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Certainty levels (from 100% to 0%) within the 1P reserves.

table-wrap.anchoringText: Finally, three deterministic scenarios - “Low”, “Base” and “High” – are obtained from the distribution of percentiles of the total proved reserves, in order to estimate the total 1P reserves (see Table N°15).
table-wrap.label: Table N° 15
table-wrap.caption: Proved Reserves (1P) of Block XYZ- Hybrid Method.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proved Reserves (1P) of Block XYZ- Hybrid Method.

table-wrap.anchoringText: The comparison of the Proved 1P Reserves estimated by the deterministic, pseudo-probabilistic and hybrid methods is shown in Table N° 16. There is an important difference in the “Low case” and “High case” results comparing the three methodologies. This is because the hybrid model has a better management of the uncertainty spectrum, reducing the risk and providing a more precise and reliable estimation. The relative risk is measured as the standard deviation respect to the “Base case”. Table N° 16 shows that the less relative risk corresponds to the Hybrid Model.
table-wrap.label: Table N°16
table-wrap.caption: Proved 1P Reserves estimated by the deterministic, pseudo-probabilistic and hybrid methods for Block XYZ.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proved 1P Reserves estimated by the deterministic, pseudo-probabilistic and hybrid methods for Block XYZ.
